Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal will analyze the structure of moduli spaces, i.e., versions of parameter spaces, in the context of superstrings propagating on Calabi-Yau manifolds. Three moduli spaces will be considered: the space of N=(2,2) superconformal field theories, which relates directly to the moduli space of the Calabi Yau threefolds; the space of N=(0,2) superconformal field theories, which extends this notion to something closer to real physics and is associated with the moduli spaces of vector bundles; and D-branes on a fixed Calabi Yau manifold which is associated to the moduli space of stable objects in the derived category.

Superstring theory is a model of fundamental physics expected to yield a unified description of fundamental particle physics and the structure of spacetime. While this theory has yet to make contact with experimental physics, its impact and success in field of mathematics in areas such as algebraic geometry is beyond doubt. The proposed research intends to both build on established links between methods of theoretical physics and geometry, and pursue as yet unexplored connections. The main notion explored in this proposal is the idea of a set of all possible mathematically consistent theories. This notion can be pursued in the language of either theoretical physics or mathematics. Comparisons between these languages then often yields new ideas and results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The superstring model of fundamental physics is a model in which fundamental particles are assumed to be made up of very short lengths of string as opposed to being point-like. Requiring that a theory of such string-like objects be compatible with the physics of quantum mechanics puts very strong constraints on the theory. In particular,the standard picture of there being four dimensions of spacetime appears to be incompatible.


This research considers certain kinds of models for the geometry of spacetime which is compatible with string theory. Strikingly, the properties demanded by physics for these geometries coincides with some of the most interesting current research in pure mathematics,particularly in the field of algebraic geometry.


Algebraic geometry is the study of geometry by drawing graphs of functions. The algebraic properties of the functions are related to the geometric properties of their graphs. Algebraic geometry is particularly powerful when it is used in the context of complex numbers, which effectively doubles the number of dimensions of more familiar, real numbers. So, for example, the graph of a function inside a space of four complex dimensions looks like a shape of three complex dimensions. A particular class of such shapes consists of so-called Calabi-Yau manifolds. Such manifolds first came to prominence because the understanding of their properties lay just beyond what can currently be done easily in pure mathematics. However,they also happen to furnish exactly what is required for the geometryof string theory.


Calabi-Yau manifolds can be deformed and one speaks of having a family of a certain type of Calabi-Yau manifold. The members of this family depend on parameters which, when varied, change the sizes and precise shape of the Calabi-Yau manifold. The space of such parameters iscalled the moduli space. A typical member of the family is smooth all over, but at particular points in the moduli space, a Calabi-Yau space can acquire singularities where this is no longer true. In many ways,these are the most interesting points in the moduli space and the locus of these points is called the "discriminant". (A simplified picture of a discriminant is included as a figure.) As well as the geometry becoming singular, the associated physics of the corresponding string theory also becomes special in some way. This typically involves certain objects that might appear as fundamental particles becoming massless. A particular class of such objects areknown as D-branes. These D-branes form the closest link to current areas of interest (the "derived category") in algebraic geometry.


Parts of the discriminant can be labeled by small numbers called multiplicities. Methods for computing these numbers have been well understood for the past 30 years but what these numbers mean in the context of string theory is not entirely clear. The research sheds some light on this by linking it to properties of D-branes.

Another way of analyzing the discriminant is to consider what happens when we follow paths in the moduli space that loop around parts of the discriminant. This is known as "monodromy". Again, there is both an interpretation of this monodromy in terms of physics and in terms of algebraic geometry. Connecting these ideas is fascinating and was the subject of much of this research.


Singular Calabi-Yau spaces can sometimes be considered as members of more than one family. That is they can be deformed to be made smooth in two different ways that correspond to qualitatively (to be precise,topologically) different shapes. This allows for geometrical transitions between different families. This research furthered our understanding of such transitions by explaining them in terms of "exoflop" transitions where part of the Calabi-Yau manifold appears to be ejected. The ejected part of the manifold was also shown to correspond to the difference between the D-branes present in both families.

 
Another directions of research studied a more difficult class of string models called (0,2)-models. Their moduli space is much harder to understand. In particular the string picture of the moduli space can be quite different to the moduli space a geometer would use. In a particularly simple class of spaces (resolutions oforbifolds of C3) this difference was studied. In particular, a set of such models would have different dimensions according to geometry but would coincide in string theory. The combinatorics of these constructions are shown in an accompanying figure. These differences could only be partially explained in this research.
